title: Netanyahu vows to annexe Jewish settlements in occupied West Bank – GENRIKO NEWS AGGREGATOR APP
content:
Israeli prime minister’s pledge seen as a rallying call in tight election race. Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has pledged to annex Jewish settlements in the occupied Palestinian territories if he wins his country’s election on Tuesday, a dramatic last-minute rallying call to his nationalist base.
In interviews with domestic media ahead of the polls, Netanyahu repeated his promise and said he would prevent the establishment of a Palestinian state by “controlling the entire area”.
Hundreds of thousands of settlers live in outposts in the West Bank, which Israel’s military captured in a war more than half a century ago and continues to rule, controlling the lives of more than 2.5 million Palestinians.
World powers consider the settlements illegal under international law, built on land confiscated from Palestinian families and squeezing them into ever-smaller enclaves. Formally declaring the settlements part of Israel would also be seen as putting an end to fading hopes for a Palestinian state, as there would be little continuous land on which to create it.
Rapper Tamer Nafar urges Palestinians not to boycott Israel poll Read more
Netanyahu is facing a tight race for re-election. Recent polls have shown his rightwing Likud party just behind the Blue and White party, run by a former Israeli army chief Benny Gantz. However, with support from smaller pro-settlement, far-right and ultranationalist parties, Netanyahu would have a better chance of forming a coalition government.
During Israel’s last election, in 2015, Netanyahu was criticised for a poll-day statement, seen as incendiary and racist, to rally rightwing supporters by warning that Arab citizens in Israel were “heading to the polling stations in droves”. Without certain victory in sight this year, many had been waiting for a similar stunt.
On Saturday night, Netanyahu gave an interview to Israel’s Channel 12 TV. He pledged not to dismantle a single Jewish settlement, of which there are more than 100, from makeshift trailer parks on hilltops to huge townships indistinguishable from towns in Israel.
The interviewer asked why he had not already annexed some of the larger settlements. “Who says that we won’t do it? We are on the way and we are discussing it,” he replied. “You are asking whether we are moving on to the next stage – the answer is yes, we will move to the next stage. I am going to extend sovereignty and I don’t distinguish between settlement blocs and the isolated settlements.
“From my perspective, any point of settlement is Israeli, and we have responsibility, as the Israeli government. I will not uproot anyone, and I will not transfer sovereignty to the Palestinians.”
A so-called two-state solution , which envisions an Israel and a Palestine side by side, has long been the preferred peace option of most of the international community. But growing settlement construction has dashed hopes.
In a separate interview on Sunday, Netanyahu boosted about adding new housing units into settlements. “We’re going to continue controlling the entire territory west of the Jordan (river),” he said, in reference to the occupied West Bank.
Donald Trump’s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel’s capital early in his term as US president further damaged the two-state ideal. The Palestinians see the occupied eastern section of Jerusalem as the capital of any future state, and cut contact with Washington after the declaration.
Last month, Trump recognised Israeli sovereignty over the Golan Heights , a plateau Israel captured from Syria in the same 1967 conflict and annexed in 1981. The move broke from the post-second world war international consensus that forbids territorial conquest during war, and Palestinians warned that it set a dangerous precedent for land grabs in the West Bank.
Trump provokes global anger by recognising Israel's claim to Golan Heights Read more
In Israel, Trump’s announcement was viewed as an election gift to Netanyahu. On Saturday evening, Trump said he had made the controversial decision after getting a “quick” history lesson from his son-in-law Jared Kushner and his pro-settlement ambassador to Israel and former bankruptcy lawyer, David Friedman.
Trump said when he suggested US recognition, Friedman was thrilled and reacted like a “wonderful, beautiful baby” getting what he wanted. “He [Friedman] said: ‘You would do that, sir?’” Trump told the audience to chuckles.
Aaron Rupar (@atrupar) Trump describes US Ambassador to Israel David Friedman as "like a wonderful, beautiful baby." pic.twitter.com/kTv768ZQk5
April 6, 2019 Saeb Erekat , a veteran former Palestinian negotiator, said he was not surprised by Netanyahu’s statement on settlements.
“Israel will continue to brazenly violate international law for as long as the international community will continue to reward Israel with impunity, particularly with the Trump administration’s support and endorsement of Israel’s violation of the national and human rights of the people of Palestine,” he said.
Netanyahu’s remarks were also criticised by his main election challenger, former military chief Benny Gantz, who branded them calling it an “irresponsible” bid for votes.
“Why not ask how in 13 years Netanyahu could have annexed and didn’t?” said Gantz, in reference to Netanyahu’s time as premier. “I think that releasing a strategic and historic decision in an election campaign bubble is not serious and (is) irresponsible.”
Topics Israel Benjamin Netanyahu Palestinian territories Middle East and North Africa Saeb Erekat news

title: Channel Nine begins work on drama based on Lawyer X scandal | Media | The Guardian
content:
Produced by the makers of Underbelly, the series titled Informer 3838 is pitched as a ‘rollercoaster of ambition, love, delusion, murder and epic betrayal’. Channel Nine has begun pre-production work on a new television drama based on the life of former Melbourne lawyer Nicola Gobbo, better known as Lawyer X .
The production has been the subject of speculation since revelations about a lawyer acting as a police informer prompted the Andrews government to call a royal commission in December .
Gobbo, who was designated Informer 3838 in police records, was a key police informer from 2005 to 2009 at the tail end of Melbourne’s bloody gangland wars.
Screentime, the Australian production company behind the award-winning Underbelly series on the gangland wars, will produce the series which will begin filming later this year.
“Informer 3838 is the incredible gangland war story that has it all – a rollercoaster of ambition, love, delusion, murder and epic betrayal,” Michael Healy, Nine’s director of television, said in a statement on Sunday.
“It promises to be an explosive series about a well-connected young lawyer who put her life on the line, representing Melbourne’s underworld in court, and giving information about their criminal exploits to the police.”
Lawyer X: the extraordinary story laid out before royal commission Read more
Gobbo’s former clients include murdered kingpin Carl Williams and his associate Tony Mokbel, who is currently in jail for drug trafficking.
Both were figures in the previous instalments on Underbelly, and Nine reported that it was possible the actors who played them — including Gyton Grantly, who won a Logie for his portrayal of Williams and is in the middle of a long run at Melbourne’s Princes Theatre as Ron Weasley in the Australian production of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child — could reprise their roles.
Mokbel is among those challenging the validity of his conviction after the high court last year ruled that Gobbo’s former clients be informed of her double role , saying that passing on confidential information to police was a “fundamental and appalling breach” of her professional duty.
Gangsters, cops and Lawyer X: the police informant scandal that has shocked Australia Read more
The court also said Victoria Police were “guilty of reprehensible conduct” in asking Gobbo to work as an informant, despite knowing that she was a barrister.
The royal commission into the management of police informants has heard that Gobbo was registered as an informant twice in the 1990s before being registered again in 2005 , and that police did not seek legal advice on the risk of using a lawyer as a source.
The royal commission is due to make a preliminary report on 1 July and a final report on 1 December.
Topics Nine Entertainment Television Australian media news

As an Albion fan, I am very happy with the performance, and that says everything you need to know about the difference between the "Big Six" and the rest of the league. I shouldn't be happy, we just lost a cup final. But happy I am, because we gave it a go and didn't lay down and die. And we only lost by one goal.
Sadly long gone are the days when you go into such a game with a realistic chance. These days, if you are playing teams like Man City you know you need a fluke, one of those lucky, lucky days that don't come along very often. I guess our lucky, lucky day was in the last round at Millwall.

title: The no-deal Brexit genie is out of the bottle – cartoon | Opinion
content:
As much as I dislike our current first past the post system, we should be careful what we wish for....
I have always supported PR, but am not so sure now, given the fact that the political landscape in most Western democracies has changed radically over the past decade or two.
I currently live in Sweden. I don’t know how much you know about Swedish politics, but for decades the Social Democrats held power, with an occasional Moderaterna (Tory-ish) interlude.
That bloc consensus has been thrown into total disarray by the emergence of the far-right Sverigedemokraterna party. The same thingg is happening in Germany with AfD.
As archaic as our system might seem, it does curtail the potential for radical parties (we can’t help the fact that the Tories are a mainstream radical party) to gain influence or even assume the role of ”kingmakers”

title: The no-deal Brexit genie is out of the bottle – cartoon | Opinion
content: They will implode. The Eurosceptics have been lying dormant since Major put them away and Cameron opened the cellar door to let them out again and they're making up for lost time and very determined. The big problem for the Tory party is their supporters. Swelled by ex-kippers and already a big band of hardcore Eurosceptics supporters that never left, they have the weight behind the party and supporters like d'Ancona will leave if the party end up in Johnson's control. This ain't over yet, already the Tory MPs are stressed and feeling the heat and will continue long after Brexit and this is still at the deal stage, we're not even out of the door yet. Brexit will engulf the party.

title: The no-deal Brexit genie is out of the bottle – cartoon | Opinion
content: It's a fair point. As a socialist parliamentarian I have found Anna Sourby quite inspirational on this issue. I also admired the way she dealt with the intimidating brute abuse she got from Leavers walking to work one morning.

title: The no-deal Brexit genie is out of the bottle – cartoon | Opinion
content: Uh oh. Vanishing post syndrome strikes again.

title: The no-deal Brexit genie is out of the bottle – cartoon | Opinion
content:
NO European elections. We mustn't. Absolutely not.
that's exactly the sentiment on the continent. why should we allow people, who are about to leave anyway, to have a vote on our future?

title: The no-deal Brexit genie is out of the bottle – cartoon | Opinion
content: Let us see the first policy meeting on austerity, or another that doesn't involve brexit. Maybe we will see the true colours of the Cuckoos.

title: The no-deal Brexit genie is out of the bottle – cartoon | Opinion
content: The far right will prosper as we crawl around the world with our begging bowls looking for trade deals, any deal, to help our ailing economy. The economic fundamentals aren’t great- our anaemic growth seemingly based upon debt rather than investment. Who will be our new masters - China or USA?

title: Weyes Blood: Titanic Rising review – beauty deep enough to drown in | Music
content:
Yes. 'From Middle English throm' and even like Old English 'tunge-þrum' and 'from Proto-Germanic *þrumą.' It seems even to be cognate with the word 'drum' which is interesting. It has an idea of 'edge' and, here, low-frequency sound to it basally possibly I tend to think. This historico-lingustic pattern means it is an Indo-European and therefore Nostratic and Euro-Asiatic word that is literally older than history itself.
The dissonance I notice sometimes between my ideolect and a 'new' or unfamiliar word I read causes me to have the same feeling of doubt sometimes, though, feeling 'that can't possibly exist linguistically but that is an illusion, a confusion of langue and parole. But then so is the alt right.
'Langue' means 'tongue', and 'tongues' have a 'thrum'. Hence Trump.

title: The whale with legs shows how little we know about Earth’s fantastical past | Riley Black | Opinion
content: Just think. Fossils only occur on very specific conditions. We have no idea of the variety of life. The fossil record literally gives us .1 percent of even that.
